results.title: BeDevil
results.creator_credit: Tracey Moffatt, Anthony Buckley, Carol Hughes and Southern Star Entertainment
results.brief_description: BeDevil is an astounding work of Australian cinema which combines iconography drawn from Aboriginal culture and mythology, urban Australia, and popular culture. Comprising three ghost stories, all of which deal with the nature of memory and loss, this film playfully subverts the conventional linkings between aboriginality and spirituality. In “Mr. Chuck” the ghost of a US soldier haunts a billabong. In “Choo Choo Choo Choo” Ruby, (played by director Tracey Moffatt), and her family are haunted by an invisible train. In the final story, “Lovin’ The Spin I’m In”, a grieving Islander mother and her Greek-Australian neighbours are under the spell of the ghostly lovers, Bebe and Minnie. Drawing from influences that span across Aboriginal culture, American and European film, television and popular culture, “BeDevil” announces the birth of a new kind of Australian cinema: both indigenous and multicultural; mystical and sophisticated; innovative and pleasurable. The intoxicating cinematography is by Academy-award winning Geoff Burton and the music score is by Carl Vine. Visually stunning and metaphorically rich, this is a wonderful film.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Tracey Moffatt, Anthony Buckley, Carol Hughes and Southern Star Entertainment

results.title: Shimmer in the city
results.creator_credit: Amanda Hickey and Special Broadcasting Service Corporation
results.brief_description: A detailed look at urban Aboriginal art through interviews with artists, national and international curators, art dealers and art critics, and their views on the place of the work in relation to traditional Aboriginal art as well as Australian society at large. The notion of preconceived ideas of Aboriginal art is discussed as well as the non-stereotypical aboriginality represented in the urban artist’s work where mythical, cultural and environmental heritage is referred to, but situated politically as a confrontation of past and present issues effecting indigenous Australians. Through the interviews with the artists and critics of their work the autobiographical nature of the art is evoked, underlining both the personal and broad social relevance of the art to contemporary Aboriginal experience. It is thorough documentary on the broad spectrum of work being produced that also raises the key issues of Aboriginal ownership of imagery and the question of Aboriginal copyright.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Amanda Hickey and Special Broadcasting Service Corporation

results.title: Australia's art of the Dreamtime: Quinkin country
results.creator_credit: Jim Needham and WIPB-TV, Ball State University
results.brief_description:
A documentary on the history of Australian First Nations peoples and their rock art in the Cape York Peninsula region of Queensland. The program explores not only the historical background of the rock paintings but theorises on the first arrival of First Nations peoples to this land and the formation of the landscape itself through archaeological, geological and palaeontological evidence.
During the 1950s Australian artist and author Percy Trezise went on a quest to locate the rock art around Laura in the Cape York region and through contact with First Nations elders and befriending First Nations writer, Dick Roughsey, he was eventually accepted as a “tribal brother”. In this program, Percy, using images from his own paintings, interprets First Nations Dreamtime stories, mythology and initiation ceremonies as represented by the rock paintings. He speaks of his own experiences and respect for First Nations peoples, their culture and their heritage. Voice over narration by Chris Schenkel. Note: Visual quality average - filmed on video camera. Arts 2002 and SBS Independent.

results.title: Manyu-Wana 4
results.creator_credit: David Batty, Wendy Baarda and Warlpiri Media
results.brief_description:
Episode number 4 of Series “Manyu-Wana (A)”.
This episode covers the following topics: Magic; spear-straightening in a fire and hunting for kangaroo; baby magic; words for ‘big’ and ‘little’ using different clothes being washed; collecting red ochre form a cave at Karrku, near Nyirrpi; working at the powerhouse; picking up rubbish; reading of “The Snake and the Goanna”; band magic; Nyirrpi tractor. Suitable for Primary, Secondary and Tertiary level students. In Warlpiri language with English subtitles.

results.title: Australian animals dreaming stories
results.brief_description: First Nations peoples used stories to teach their children about the laws and myths of their land. Pauline McLeod tells five stories about unique Australian animals. Each story is laced with colourful drawings. The stories featured are: ‘The Giant goanna and the black snake’; ‘The Platypus’; ‘How the kangaroo got its pouch’; ‘Why does the kookaburra laugh?’; ‘The Bunyip’.

results.title: The Landscape architects; Fire down below
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Up a gum tree”.
“The Landscape architects” David Bellamy looks at how First Nations peoples learned to tame the countryside without becoming farmers, and at what sort of diet they enjoyed. “Fire Down Below” David Bellamy looks at the secrets of survival of the Australian flora against the frequent fires which seek to destroy.

results.title: Manyu-Wana 7
results.creator_credit: David Batty, Wendy Baarda and Warlpiri Media
results.brief_description:
Episode number 7 of Series “Manyu-Wana (A)”.
This episodes covers the following topics: Magic story; school children at Willowra planting seeds for a vegetable garden; dog magic; reading of a dreamtime story, “The Crimson Cat, the Bird with a Red Breast”; words for ‘in’, ‘on’ and ‘under’; tracking a person by their footprints; song about children from local communities having fun; making a healthy stew; working at Nyirrpi store; basketball teams. Suitable for Primary, Secondary and tertiary level students. In Warlpiri language with English subtitles.

results.title: Yothu Yindi, diti murru: the videos
results.creator_credit: John Wilkinson, Martin Stauce, Stephen M Johnson, Alan James, Axolotol and Burrundi Pictures
results.brief_description: Mandawuy Yunupingu and Witiyana Marika from Yothu Yindi introduce these videos from their album “Tribal voice”. The brief introductions and the videos themselves give a simple, but telling overview of Aboriginal culture and the need for black and white society to find a common meeting place. The videos are: “Treaty”, “Mainstream”, a traditional Aboriginal dance Gudurrku = brolga”, “Treaty: Filthy Lucre mix”, “Djapana: Gapirri mix and “Tribal voice”, which encompasses a plea for all indigenous cultures to be recognised.
results.creator_credit_for_label: John Wilkinson, Martin Stauce, Stephen M Johnson, Alan James, Axolotol and Burrundi Pictures

results.title: Manyu-Wana 8
results.creator_credit: David Batty, Wendy Baarda and Warlpiri Media
results.brief_description:
Episode number 8 of Series “Manyu-Wana (A)”.
This episode covers the following topics: Planting trees; reading of “The Bird and the Snake”, a story from Willowra; words for ‘few’ and ‘many’, using children onn the Willowra school bus; tracking, spearing and cookking kangaroo; bathing, working at the butcher’s; numbers and counting; traditional-style dance about the Easter story; chips magic. Suitable for Primary, Secondary and Tertiary level students. In Warlpiri language with English subtitles.

results.title: Manyu-Wana 9
results.creator_credit: David Batty, Wendy Baarda and Warlpiri Media
results.brief_description:
Episode number 9 of Series “Manyu-Wana (A)”.
This episode covers the following topics: Cleaning up the house; words for ‘slow’ and ‘fast’; pram magic; reading “The Emu and the Crane”, a traditional story about how the emu lost its wings; working at the clinic; words for ‘North’, ‘South’, ‘East’ and ‘West’; song about making playing humpies in a creek bed; making spinifex resin; maths: 5-2=3, using eggs. Suitable for Primary, Secondary and Tertiary level students. In Warlpiri language with English subtitles.
results.creator_credit_for_label: David Batty, Wendy Baarda and Warlpiri Media
